single_hop.question: According to the manual, what status is indicated by an ORANGE LED on the Aurora Central PVI Monitor?
single_hop.ground_truth_answer: An ORANGE LED indicates that the battery is charging.
single_hop.reasoning: This question is single-hop as the answer is directly stated in one bullet point within the provided chunk. It is specific and technical, focusing on the meaning of a particular LED color on a specific device (Aurora Central PVI Monitor). The answer is clear, factual, and directly verifiable from the text. It effectively tests a RAG system's ability to retrieve the relevant section and extract the precise meaning associated with a specific status indicator.
single_hop.source_text:
Installation and Operation Manual Page 87 of 145
[PVI-CENTRAL-XXX (US or CAN) - Rev:3.0]
14.3. Front status LED signalling
The anterior part of the display contains a status LED. This LED changes colour according to the
status of Aurora Central PVI Monitor. The different operation statuses and their corresponding
colours are:
• LED OFF: No external (5Vdc) power supply.
• GREEN LED: Battery charged; at least one power supply connected (DC or USB).
• ORANGE LED: Battery is charging.
• RED LED: Low battery; no power supply connected (DC or USB).
• BLUE BLINKING LED: Aurora Central PVI Monitor ON (STAND-BY).

MENU NAVIGATION:
There are two external buttons on the AcquiSuite, Menu and Select, that are
located at the top right corner of the unit.
The Menu button is used to scroll through the menu options and Select is used to
advance into the currently displayed menu option.
After selecting DHCP+UPnP on/off, Menu will disable DHCP and Select will enable

advance the cursor a single position and the Menu button will scroll through the
number/character options for the current cursor position.

EV-2H
Aluminum Vertical
Disconnect Switch
550 kV - 800 kV
Robust Current Transfer & Hinge
Mechanism Promote Maximum Reliability
Southern States’ latest innovation, the EV-2H, supports reliability through its unique
design. This heavy duty, highly efficient vertical break disconnect switch utilizes
independent mechanical and electrical systems to produce the strongest possible
design with the easiest accessible maintenance. An over toggle mechanism in both
open and closed positions prevents the possibility for the blade to close in extreme
weather and increases down force for high fault performance. Metal encased coil
spring counterbalances reduce operating effort, are impervious to weather, and
prevent catastrophic failure that is possible with linear springs. Using an all stainless
steel bearing also ensures a long life in all operating conditions.
BENEFITS SPECIFICATIONS
• Mechanical operation is independent of the moving current joints, allowing efficient Maximum Voltage Rating

10. While conducting a lockout/tagout, I noticed the tag did not include the technician’s
full name and date. Incomplete information could cause confusion during shift
handover. The tag was corrected immediately.
11. On the way to a solar site, our truck’s low tire pressure indicator came on. We pulled
over and confirmed one tire was at 50% pressure. It was unsafe to continue until the
tire was repaired.
12. While walking a PV array row, I tripped slightly over a grounding cable that was not
secured tightly. This could easily cause a fall. I reported it and placed a cone until
repair.
13. During inverter troubleshooting, a technician reached into the cabinet without
voltage testing the bus first. I stopped them and reminded them of the test-before-
touch rule. Work resumed safely afterward.
14. At the EV charging site, I saw an extension cord being used across a walkway. It
posed a trip hazard for pedestrians. I re-routed the cord overhead with a hook.
15. While performing a harness check, I noticed one lanyard hook was cracked. Using
this could have resulted in fall arrest failure. The equipment was tagged out and
replaced.
16. Driving through a rural access road, I saw deer crossing ahead. Quick braking
prevented a collision, but it reinforced the need to watch wildlife in these areas. The
crew was reminded at tailboard.
17. At a BESS container, a technician attempted to bypass a panel interlock. I stopped
the work and reinforced that interlocks must never be bypassed. The

restocked.

785. At the control house, I saw a technician using a coffee pot on an overloaded

multi_hop.question: According to the provided contract excerpts, what are the two distinct categories of obligations or agreements that Schedule 22 of the EPC Agreement addresses for the Contractor?
multi_hop.ground_truth_answer: Schedule 22 addresses two primary categories of obligations for the Contractor: 1) It serves as a Release, Hold Harmless and Indemnification Agreement, where the Contractor agrees to waive liability for the client/purchaser, indemnify them, and assume direct responsibility for work and liabilities to the State. 2) It outlines the Purchaser's specific security procedures with which the EPC Contractor and all its Subcontractors must comply.

Chunk 1 explicitly defines Schedule #22 as the 'Release, Hold Harmless and Indemnification Agreement,' detailing the Contractor's indemnification and liability waiver responsibilities. Chunk 2, in a different context, states that the EPC Contractor and Subcontractors must comply with 'Purchaser’s specific security procedures (as outlined Schedule 22)'. To fully answer what Schedule 22 addresses, a RAG system must synthesize these two distinct functions mentioned across the documents, demonstrating multi-hop reasoning and the ability to connect references to the same schedule across different parts of a contract.

multi_hop.question: According to the National Electrical Code, what is the maximum permissible increase in rating for a 601-6000 ampere classification fuse used as a motor branch-circuit short-circuit and ground-fault protective device, and how might this general allowance be affected if the device has particular load characteristics or limitations specified as a condition of its listing?
multi_hop.ground_truth_answer: For a motor branch-circuit short-circuit and ground-fault protective device utilizing a fuse of 601-6000 ampere classification, the rating is permitted to be increased, but it shall in no case exceed 300 percent of the full-load current. However, if particular load characteristics or limitations are specified as a condition of the device's listing, those specific restrictions must be observed, regardless of the ampere rating of the load, potentially overriding the general 300 percent allowance.
multi_hop.reasoning: This question requires information from both chunks. Chunk 1 provides the specific technical detail that a fuse of 601-6000 ampere classification can be increased up to 300 percent of the full-load current for motor branch-circuit protection (430.52(4)). Chunk 2 introduces the general principle that 'particular load characteristics or limitations specified as a condition of the listing' must be observed regardless of the ampere rating. The question forces the synthesis of these two pieces of information by asking how the general fuse rating allowance might be affected by specific listing conditions, thus testing the system's ability to combine a specific rule with a general overriding principle from different parts of the code.

multi_hop.question: Given a Shark meter configured with a Pt-S (Scaling) value of '100' for a 277/277 Volt system, if this meter receives a DNP 3.0 Read (Function 1) request for its Analog Inputs at address 0x00F7, what are the specific DNP 3.0 Application Layer characteristics regarding message fragmentation and application-level confirmation for the response?
multi_hop.ground_truth_answer: For a Shark meter, such as one configured with a Pt-S (Scaling) value of '100' for a 277/277 Volt system, when responding to a DNP 3.0 Read (Function 1) request for its Analog Inputs, the Application Layer characteristics dictate that multiple-fragment messages are not allowed. Therefore, each Application Header must indicate it is both the first (FIR = 1) and final (FIN = 1) fragment. Furthermore, application-level confirmation is not used for Shark meters.
multi_hop.reasoning: This question requires information from both chunks. Chunk 2 provides the specific technical context of the Shark meter's configuration (Pt-S value of '100' for a 277/277 Volt system), establishing the scenario for the device. Chunk 1 details the DNP 3.0 communication protocol specifics for Shark meters, including valid addresses (0x00F7 is 247, a valid programmable address), the Read (Function 1) for Analog Inputs, and crucially, the Application Layer characteristics regarding message fragmentation (no multiple fragments, FIR=1, FIN=1) and application-level confirmation (not used). The answer synthesizes this by applying the communication rules from Chunk 1 to a meter specifically configured as described in Chunk 2, making the Chunk 2 information essential for setting up the specific, technical scenario and for the answer to explicitly reference the meter's context.

multi_hop.question: What specific warning label text, required to comply with 110.21(B), must be present for 60/120-volt technical power receptacles in pipe organ installations and for equipment enclosures housing selectively coordinated overcurrent devices in elevator systems, according to the National Electrical Code?
multi_hop.ground_truth_answer: For 60/120-volt technical power receptacles in pipe organ installations, the warning label complying with 110.21(B) must state: 'WARNING-TECHNICAL POWER Do not connect to lighting equipment. For electronic equipment use only. 60/120 V. 1ac GFCI protected'. For equipment enclosures housing selectively coordinated overcurrent devices in elevator systems, the marking complying with 110.21(B) must state: 'CAUTION: OVERCURRENT DEVICES IN THIS ENCLOSURE ARE SELECTIVELY COORDINATED. EQUIVALENT REPLACEMENTS AND TRIP SETTINGS ARE REQUIRED.'
multi_hop.reasoning: This question requires information from both Document 1 (Article 650, Pipe Organs) and Document 2 (Article 620, Elevators). It specifically asks for the distinct warning label text mandated by the National Electrical Code for two different applications, both of which are required to comply with 110.21(B). Answering this question necessitates identifying the common regulatory reference (110.21(B)) and then extracting the specific, technical warning language associated with it from each document, thereby testing the ability to synthesize information across different sections of the code.
